Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Three-Dimensional Porous Nanographene for Highly Efficient Energy Storage in Li-Ion Batteries

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Gang Wu
Proposal Number: 1511528

Rechargeable lithium ion batteries support the development of sustainable energy systems by storing electricity generated by renewable resources such as wind and solar energy, or by powering zero-emission electric vehicles charged by electricity from renewable resources. However, the storage capacity, recharging time, and power output from current lithium ion batteries must improve to enable further market penetration for electric vehicles. The goal of this project is to redesign the carbon electrode of the battery to make fundamental improvements in performance. The new carbon electrode will be based on graphene, a form of carbon that is ordered into sheets one atom thick. New methods will be developed to form graphene into a three-dimensional structure designed through scientific principles to provide high capacity, rapid recharge times, and stability during repeated charging. The educational activities associated with this project include summer research experiences for three undergraduate students from under-represented groups in engineering, and hands-on outreach to elementary schools in the Buffalo, New York area.

Nanostructured graphene has emerged as a potentially transformative material for replacing porous carbon in the anode of rechargeable lithium ion batteries for transportation applications because it offers the potential for high surface area and electronic conductivity, leading to higher capacity and faster charge/discharge rates. However, under repeated charge/discharge cycles, the storage capacity fades rapidly because the graphene sheets restack. New synthesis approaches for nanographene are needed to address this problem and to extend the capabilities of graphene for use in lithium ion battery anodes. The overall goals of this proposed research are to rationally design stable, three-dimensional graphene anodes of defined structure and electronic properties for lithium ion batteries through atomic level self-assembly and heteroatom substitution, and then develop a fundamental understanding of lithium ion insertion and extraction processes in this anode. The proposed research has three objectives. The first objective is to develop new and scalable synthetic protocols to prepare a series of structurally stable, nitrogen(N)-doped nanographenes with functional linkers via Suzuki coupling and covalent stabilization, and then fine-tune the lattice geometry and electronic properties of the final three-dimensional structure through controlled d-lattice spacing and N-doping level. Material properties will be characterized by photoluminescence, nuclear magnetic resonance, and mass spectroscopies. The second objective is to establish a fundamental understanding of lithium ion adsorption, desorption, and diffusion kinetics on doped nanographene using nanographene model systems of well-defined molecular size, structure, and doping. Towards this end, in situ electrochemical neutron experiments complimented by high-resolution transmission electron microscope imaging and microanalysis techniques will be used to measure changes in composition, structure, and thermodynamic processes of graphene anodes during lithium ion insertion/extraction reactions. The lithium reaction mechanisms on nitrogen-doped nanographene will be investigated computationally by Density Functional Theory (DFT) and nanoscale dynamic simulation. The third objective is to design and synthesize structured three-dimensional porous nanographene anode materials with chemical and structural properties designed to optimize lithium capacity, diffusion rate, and cyclic stability. Research outcomes will also be used to develop instructional materials for a new course on advanced energy materials at the University of Buffalo.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) are the most suitable power sources for electric vehicle (EV) applications, because of their highest energy density and best reliability when compared to other battery technologies. However, current LIBs still cannot provide enough long driving-distance for EVs after a single charge (< 160 km or 100 miles). The primary reasons are the overall low energy density, partially due to the use of current graphite anodes with insufficient capacity.

 This NSF project is to addresses the issue by exploring new concepts and materials through designing and synthesizing innovative high-performance anode materials for LIBs. In particular, we focused on the synthesis of structurally and chemically defined organic compounds such as nanographene, functionalized C60, and metal-organic framework (MOF) materials as the new anode in LIBs.

The primary outcomes of this project include experimental and theoretical advances in battery material development. In terms of the performance improvement, the new 3D nanographene with optimal functionalization exhibited ca. three-time capacity of the state-of-the-art graphite up to 900 mAh/g capable of maintaining charging-discharging cyclic stability up to 100 cycles. Also, the functionalized C60 anode also delivered a significantly enhanced capacity up to 1000 mAh/g with sufficient cyclic stability. The structural and chemical defined MOF anodes also presented very encouraging capacity and stability during battery studies. This project also yielded a set of innovative synthetic methods to prepared those organic compounds with accurate controls of functionalization and dopants. In addition, fundamental understanding of lithium ion adsorption/desorption mechanisms and diffusion kinetics was obtained on doped graphene by elucidating well-defined nanographene model systems (e.g., molecular size, structure, and doping content and location). The synthesis-structure-reactivity correlations was established. First-principles calculations were used to assist in the interpretation of electrochemical and battery results, then provided theoretical guidance for rational nanographene design and synthesis. These scientific knowledge has been documented in well-known peer-reviewed journal publications including Advanced Materials, Nano Energy, ACS Applied Materials and Interfaces, and Journal of Materials Chemistry, which are available and relevant to researchers throughout many fields of science and engineering to apply the results towards new processes and technologies that will inevitably benefit society.

The new research outcomes have been successfully incorporated into a few courses including “Electrochemical Energy and Environmental Technologies”, “Materials Science and Engineering”, “Polymers”, and “Computer-Aided Research in the Chemical and Materials Disciplines, which has been benefiting for the education of undergraduate and graduate students in the Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering at the University at Buffalo, SUNY. During the project, multiple leveled students received trainings on electrochemistry, materials synthesis and characterization, battery technologies, and computational studies. A Ph.D. student, Hangguang Zhang, partially supported by this NDF project was graduated in early this year and now is a postdoctoral research associated at Los Alamos National Laboratory. An African American graduate student, Anix Casimir, received comprehensive trainings on electrochemistry and battery in this project, now is a research scientist in a battery company. A female undergraduate Dana Havas, who worked in the PI’s group on this project for two years, now is a Ph.D. candidate at Cornell University. She also received an NSF Graduate Research Fellowships Program (GRFP) award in 2017. This NSF project also partially help build a battery laboratory in the Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering at University at Buffalo, which is currently used as an infrastructure for a project designed for “Chemical Engineering Lab” for junior undergraduate students.

 These outcomes will further generate broader impacts on the development of a variety of energy storage materials and provide essential principles for engineering of a variety of energy systems, which are currently a fast expending science and engineering research frontier. The scientific progress will lay a solid foundation for technological innovation in developing graphene-based anodes with sufficient capacity and cyclic stability, which will make LIB technologies more suitable for highly-demanded transportation applications.
